newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan April jobless rate at 2.59 percent.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan April jobless rate at 2.59 percent.

text.p: Taiwan's unemployment rate was 2.59 percent in April, lower than government and private economists had expected, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics said on Friday.
The April joblessness figure came in significantly below an average 2.896 forecast compiled from a May 21 Reuters Poll of Taiwan economists.

Directorate economists found the relatively low figure surprising as well, noting that the impact of an islandwide outbreak of hog foot-and-mouth disease in March and a related ban on Taiwan's huge pork exports was unexpectedly small.
"The impact of the hog epidemic was lower than expected," a directorate official told Reuters as the figure was issued.
The April unemployment figure not only was lower than the month-earlier level of 2.79 percent in March, but was the lowest in 11 months. Joblessness in May 1996 was 2.35 percent.
Because Taiwan's hog-farm crisis erupted on March 20, April was the first full month to reflect its economic impact.

At first, government and private economists widely concurred that the scaling back of Taiwan's huge export-related feedlot and meatpacking industry would seriously add to joblessness. Pork export had been a US$1.56 billion-a-year industry.
Initial estimates ran as high as 50,000 jobs lost, which would have added 0.5-0.6 percentage points to unemployment.
Some economists more recently had revised their estimates of the farm epidemic's impact to 20,000 jobs lost.
Directorate officials said on Friday that precise figures for epidemic-related job losses would not be available before mid-June, but said they did not expect the numbers to be high.
"The unemployed population will not increase sharply (due to the foot and mouth epidemic)," agency director Chen Chang-hsiung told reporters after announcing the April figures.

Besides banning all pork exports temporarily, the government responded to the outbreak by ordering the slaughter of all hogs, even healthy ones, at all affected farms -- or about four million of Taiwan's 14 million pigs.

Other factors contributed significantly to April's month-on-month unemployment decline, chiefly a steadily accelerating recovery, which added jobs in the manufacturing and long-struggling construction sectors, Chen said.
The directorate said the number of unemployed people in April decreased by 20,000 to 242,000 from March.
The number of employed fell 4,000 to 9.119 million, but jobs in industrial sectors rose by 46,000, it said.
